title: The Toyota FT-86, GT-86, Scion FRS - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text: I bought a GT86 thanks to Chris Harris.﻿
comments.author: arioz1

comments.text:
Was this guy hungover and on cocaine in this video? Why is he acting so 
fucking weird?﻿
comments.author: Shaun Cooney

comments.text:
People who "get" this car are the ones who, on a night they can't sleep or 
wake up early (doh!) on a Saturday morning...go for a drive. It's 4 AM, the 
streets are quiet, it's still dark and it's just you and the car...grab a 
coffee and hit the road. There's no other way to explain it.﻿
comments.author: GrandOldTunes

comments.text: more videos on the gt86!﻿
comments.author: spendarthegreat

comments.text: Should of put a 2.5L Boxer instead of the 2.0L Boxer ﻿
comments.author: touge410

comments.text:
+touge410 that engine is quite a big bigger. I have a 86 and have obviously 
driven it in both stock form (147kw) and my current tuned form (in the 
185kw/320nm region) The car with 185kw and 320nm is absolutely perfect. Now 
I still have the 2L boxer, its still N/A with only mods being, e85 tune, 
intake, exhaust and pulleys. So there is definite potential in the FA20 to 
make more power. At this level of power, the tires need to be changed, what 
is fun on stock power, is downright dangerous with 185kw. Sliding without 
even trying and deadly in the wet.
comments.author: stinger15au

comments.text:
I agree, especially given the fact that they kept in N/A, and they could 
have grabbed it right out of an Impreza. But I think Subaru got caught up 
in the "Horsepower-per-Liter" bandwagon...
comments.author: Patrick Jane

comments.text:
Now, Here is a fellow that has driven Pagani, Ferrari, Lamborghini, 
Bugatti, McLaren and such.

And he gets just about the same reaction and excitement from a car that 
cost just around £25,000!﻿
comments.author: ENZOtaki

comments.text:
strange thing is that they have been a bit of a sales disaster, which is 
great, as the price just came down 20% in Thailand﻿
comments.author: fish fingers

comments.text:
+fish fingers depends on where. They have sold nearly 15,000 in Australia, 
a HUGE amount of the sports car market, and a still significant 0.8% of ALL 
car and they are everywhere. Many are left stock, some lightly modified and 
some turned into full on race cars. Owners are everyone from a kid getting 
their first car to 60yr olds wanting something fun and everything in 
between. Here in Australia they have been a HUGE success
comments.author: stinger15au

comments.text:
Dude, you are an awesome drifter. You don't come off as such a talented 
driver (no offense) rather than someone who just pays attention to detail 
but the smoothness you keep with a car is uncanny. I love my FR-S.﻿
comments.author: Nickel Reed

comments.text:
Nah I just know he does car reviews. Is he a former race car driver or 
something?
comments.author: Nickel Reed

comments.text: Do you know who this guy is? =))
comments.author: Mejevoli

comments.text:
3 years of ownership and I still love driving the car on twisty mountain 
roads at dawn.  Chris Harris is right, this car is not about laptimes, or 
acceleration, or corner speeds. It does not need to be faster to be better. 
It is better because of what it is and what it can do.﻿
comments.author: mike cassey

comments.text:
+mike cassey yep, im coming up on 18months and 60,000km. Its still an 
amazing car that makes me smile every single day, and importantly at speeds 
that won't get you thrown in jail.
comments.author: stinger15au

comments.text:
I think he might like the GT86 more than the old Miata.  I wonder what 
he'll think of the newer 2016 ND MX5 Miata.﻿

i am 51. had something like 26 cars. had the GT86 for three months now an

comments.text:
+Dheevesh M couldn't give a toss about brand image to be honest. They are 
the same comfort wise, it is faster,and the Porsche is a better car, no 
doubt about it, but its not triple the price better. Your getting 90% of 
the package for 30% of the price. A good deal.
comments.author: stinger15au

comments.text:
+stinger15au Whether the 86 is close to the Porsche is arguable as the 
Porsche has a better brand image, is more comfortable and if you like 
speed, it is faster too... But without any doubt, the 86 definitely has a 
better value for money.

comments.text:
Too weak.  If I'm going to buy a rwd , long nosed coupe, it's not going to 
be a naturally aspirated Subaru dressed in Toyota (or the Subaru version 
either).  I'm not saying it's a bad car, but it's basically just a rwd 
Subaru with no balls.﻿
comments.author: Shock Diamond

comments.text:
I used to have a Ford Cougar, and loved it. It had a few flaws, including 
front wheel drive, but I loved it. Great looking, practical, handled nicely 
and fast enough for the road but great and economical on a long trip. I 
always wondered what I would replace it with when age inevitably crept up 
on it. There was nothing else out there unless you want to fork our for a 
Jag or an Aston.

As it happens I ditched the "practical" and went for an MX-5, a bit quicker 
than the cat and handles like ... well if everyone here is to be believed 
like a GT86. It is a fantastic car.

Now I have an answer. When I want to get back to what I had in the Cougar I 
will get a GT86. I came here because I love the look of it, and was curious 
if it was RWD, and am so pleased that Toyota gave it the handling it has. 
Glad to see someone is doing for coupés what Mazda did for roadsters, and 
what Ford sadly failed to do 15 years or so ago.﻿
comments.author: Doubting Rich

comments.text: QUIERO ESE AUTOO!!!!﻿
comments.author: Franco Mattos

comments.text:
Too much exhaust "noise" so I couldn't hear half of his comments while on 
the circuit.﻿
comments.author: Rusty White

comments.text:
being a STi owner, the FRS is THE WORST car I have EVER driven. Granted 
I've only ever driven cars more expensive with more power. okay, let me be 
more specific. The clutch engagement is way too high, the shifter takes too 
much effort to put in gear, the shifter placement is too far forward (maybe 
I have long legs and short arms?) and the clutch has ZERO feed back and way 
too light. I know it lacks power, but it does not contribute to a bad 
driving experience, and I'm sorry but the godly handling just doesn't make 
up for the bad manual. and I'm talking about driving like a sensible person 
on the STREET not on the track where the superb handling just doesn't shine 
what so ever.﻿
comments.author: gwot

comments.text:
The clutch grab point can be easily adjusted and the Subaru trans fluid 
does nothing to help the already fairly notchy shifter. Most guys that buy 
them swap trans fluid pretty early and notice a world of difference in 
shifter feel. All you would have to do is change the fluid and adjust the 
clutch pedal. The shifter position won't fit everybody though.
comments.author: Corie Burk

comments.text:
+TheAsianblu I agree it's probably my wording, that is why I'm correcting 
you. and AGAIN I'm strictly talking about street driving, where most cars 
will feel the same, this does NOT include any form of spirited or track or 
mountain driving, which is NOT NOT NOT the feeling i want. I 100% know what 
the FRS is capable of and what it's designed for, but that's not what I do 
with a car, that's is why I prefer the STi over the FRS, because of what 
"I" personally do with a car, is drive it on the streets like a grandma. 
and i personally prefer a heavier clutch with lower engaging point, which 
the FRS does NOT offer. that is IT. i'll say this again, the FRS is good, 
but the STi is just better. I'm sorry, I enjoy my cars without wheel spin, 
which is what the STi is designed to do, grip. and it snows where I live, 
so I get plenty of fun sliding around. but thank you for understanding it's 
just my opinion.
comments.author: gwot

comments.text:
No... You don't know how to word what you are saying... Just say it was 
terrible because the STi FEELS better to you (I won't say YOU because I 
know it's YOUR opinion). I've read and watched reviews from people who have 
driven almost everything (like the guys from EverydayDriver) and they said 
everything opposite of what you said... I can feel the STi clutch engage... 
First time driving the 86 it was smooth. Go cruising through the mountains 
with a lot of winding turns with both cars. You don't have to try... with 
the 86... You just drive and just from hearing the wheels slip just a 
bit... That's the feeling you want. With the STi you probably have to TRY 
to enjoy the ride with no cars around to bow down to your presence...
comments.author: TheAsianblu

comments.text:
+TheAsianblu I've never said anything about the height of the seat, I liked 
the FRS seat/position more than my STi... so I dont know what you're 
talking about, maybe you got influenced by the other guy who also 
"misunderstanding" what I'm saying and putting words into my mouth. Yes, 
higher HP/TQ will need a heavier clutch, but heavy clutch does not mean 
more power (I can replace the stock FRS clutch with a heavier one and the 
power won't change, but i'll be happy).  Disliking a light clutch DOES NOT, 
i repeat DOES NOT, mean I dislike the power. So no, that's not what i was 
saying, it's how YOU understood it. It does not matter how effortless you 
can shift, fact is, my STi shifts smoother. The FRS has a good shifter, 
just my STi is "better" is what I'm getting at.
comments.author: gwot

comments.text:
As a heavy casual driver... I'm not too sure what you are talking about. I 
think in general everything you've complained about is based on your 
driving habits and the lack of power of the FRS, yet you're trying to make 
it sound like you aren't complaining about the power. More HP will result 
in a heavier clutch. It rides lower than everything you've mentioned... If 
you're riding like a thug or just slamming the seat way when you aren't 
that tall... you definitely will have a tough time with the clutch. Also it 
doesn't take much to throw it in gear... I was even able to flip it into 
gear with no effort using my pinky... So I'll reword your "comment". (I had 
a bad driving experience because the car did not have enough power and 
because I like driving with my ass not hovering above the asphalt) I'm not 
verbally attacking you... Just showing you what exactly you're saying...

PS the godly handling saved my life. This is some advice I'd like to give 
all FRS/GT86/BRZ drivers... Please take your car to the track at least once 
and get a feel for sliding/drifting. It may or may not save you one day. I 
was driving in heavy rain and hit a very very slippery pavement on the road 
while turning. My car flew sideways (due to the slippery pavement + rain + 
weight of the car) and since I was "used" to the sliding feeling... I was 
able to keep control of the slide and continue on my "heart racing merry 
way".
comments.author: TheAsianblu

comments.text:
+bkblitzed I think you too are missing my point, I don't like the clutch 
weight, shift into gear feel, and shifter position. THAT'S IT. stick shift 
aside, I'm sure it's more fun to drive when "at their limit" which again, 
was not one of my gripes as I will probably never do so. and I drive the 
2013 STi, much different car than the 04
comments.author: gwot

comments.text:
+gwot having owned both an 04 sti and my current frs and pushing them 
towards their limit on autox, and on track the frs Is more enjoyable than 
the sti. Also It's much better at getting feedback from the road.
comments.author: BK

comments.text:
+Hakeem Al-Kazak We're just going in circles here. My point is, I don't 
drive the car hard enough to feel the difference between chassis or 
drivetrain set ups, from a simple driving in a straight line at speed limit 
perspective, the FRS isn't the car FOR ME, as I didn't like how the 
clutch/shifter felt. and I did work for Honda but never drove a S2000, 
that's why I didn't mention it, but I did work for Ford and drove tons of 
mustang V6, V8, boss and shelby's, I LOVED THEM, if I ever get a muscle 
car, it'll be a mustang. The stang might not have handling, balance or as 
agile as the FRS, but the clutch feel and shifter just feels so good, 
THAT'll win me over getting a FRS, but If i put more power/heavier clutch 
and maybe a shifter kit, that might be a different story. Again, you are 
going on about how YOU would like to drive the car, and I get it, but still 
does not make the zero feel clutch, hard to push into gear shifter any 
better.
comments.author: gwot

comments.text:
+gwot That is the issue, you drive like grandma and compared it to a Fit, 
another sedan-like FWD car :] gotta go out and drive a Silvia, 350/370z, 
Miata, MR2, Supra, Mustang, Camaro, Challenger, S2000, RX7/RX8 and Genesis 
Coupe.  They are really the closest comparable vehicles, I've owned a 
couple of those as my DD so when I test drove the FRS/BRZ the first time it 
was a very familiar and nice feeling.  RWD and car balance contribute a lot 
to my DD experience, you don't need to be driving aggressively to swing a 
small RWD car like the FRS/BRZ around in public roads, just turn off all 
driving aids, turn sharp around corners, add some gas and slightly counter 
steer FTW.  Perhaps a much more sedate experience with FWD/AWD is your cup 
of tea which is fine, but if you worked for Honda you should know how nice 
the S2000 drives, the FRS/BRZ only takes that mid engine/neutral balanced 
RWD concept even further with an even better chassis.
comments.author: Hakeem Al-Kazak

comments.text: +Andrew Wishon but I had more fun driving a Honda fit... than the FRS
comments.author: gwot

comments.text:
Its not a drag car. The roads you drive are to straight. Of corse its less 
than a 40 or 50k sti with AWD duh.... the point is its 24k rwd.
comments.author: Andrew Wishon

comments.text:
+Hakeem Al-Kazak Sorry if it seemed like I was being aggressive, but I 
specifically mentioned how the power aspect doesn't contribute to the 
negative driving experience, reinforcing people to NOT think that "speed 
was the first big gripe" I had with the car. Your preference is totally 
fine, but your suspension and stickier tires don't make the driving 
experience any better, it just makes the handling better which, again, was 
not what I was getting at. I personally only drive on paved roads, so AWD 
ONLY becomes useful during snowfall. and unless you're gunning it or in 
muddy terrain... AWD/RWD on gravel/dirt (rural?) isn't gonna be that big of 
a difference. and as for comfort? the FRS for that short amount of time, 
was way more composed, less bouncy dampens the road imperfections better 
than my STi which is still on its stock suspension. and yes, I do drive 
like a grandpa, I seriously do. I've also mentioned a few times that my 
comparison is NOT fair, was just comparing it to my PERSONAL vehicle's 
"driving feel", not its driving dynamics which = handling of the cars.
comments.author: gwot

comments.text:
+gwot Hey, relax bro, you started with "FRS is THE WORST car I have EVER 
driven. Granted I've only ever driven cars more expensive with more power" 
guess like the Si :] regardless, so I thought speed was the first big gripe 
you had with the car.  Changing out the clutch, fine, all preference of 
course, personally would upgrade the suspension or get stickier tires over 
the clutch.  Also you said "but I haven't driven each cars to its limit 
where AWD would be a positive experience and RWD would be a negative" so I 
was replying terms of DD, I've driven several of my friends' STIs here in 
Arizona where AWD does help a lot in the more rural areas but the 
experience for the FRS/BRZ with its neutral RWD is very enjoyable, unless 
you drive like a grandma :p either way, all the cars you have mentioned, 
Si/GTI/STI are just more "comfortable" as a DD mostly because they are much 
more sedan-like with their high driving positions.  The fair DD experience 
comparison would be to look at S2000s, Miatas, RX8s and even the current 
muscle cars, they share much more similar driving dynamics.
comments.author: Hakeem Al-Kazak

comments.text:
+Hakeem Al-Kazak Sorry I didn't specify, but modding is NEVER only 
associated with HP alone, and I never said I wanted it to be a speed demon, 
it's ALL about the driving feel and no I'm not talking about handling. I'd 
change the clutch for starters to hopefully get a heavier feel to it, and 
adjust the clutch peddle so it doesn't engage so damn high. again, I didn't 
complain about the lack of power, It'd be nice though, like the Si/GTi with 
a higher low end torque. Not the low torque at almost redline BS. why do 
you keep referring to "losing traction" or "AWD" like I ever mentioned 
about RWD sucks? I am simply reviewing the FRS as a DD and streetability, 
NOT how well it corners and how easy it is to drift. Not to be rude, but 
you gotta actually read my comments, and not reply with so much irrelevancy.
comments.author: gwot

comments.text:
+gwot Why?  The BRZ/FRS is never going to ever be a real speed demon 
exactly like the Miata or even to a lesser extent S2000/RX8, all very poor 
cars to pick if you are looking for a HP machine, but the cornering speeds 
alone with the BRZ/FRS make the GTi and Si feel and look like boats.  You 
can drift even going only 20 MPH, lol.  If losing traction isn't your sort 
of thing then the WRX is probably a much better bet, but none of those cars 
come close to driving orientation and the position the BRZ/FRS provides, 
that is nearly flawless for a sports car.
comments.author: Hakeem Al-Kazak

comments.text:
+Hakeem Al-Kazak I'm definatly spoiled, comparing the FRS to a STi is not 
fair. but I haven't driven each cars to its limit where AWD would be a 
positive experience and RWD would be a negative. I've also driven the Si, I 
used to work at Honda, and I loved it, the acceleration was quick and I 
loved the shifter/clutch, even a GTi was awsome to drive, but the GTi has 
50 more torque :P all cars I've driven so far I can leave it stock and 
drive it, my STi is bone stock but the FRS is one that I HAVE TO mod for it 
to be enjoyable for me to drive.
comments.author: gwot

comments.text:
What?  The clutch was a bit odd at first but I didn't have any issues, not 
the best feeling clutch but still less vague than other stock clutches I've 
experienced.  The shifter is in a perfect spot for me and I think the 
shifts are really nice and short.  You are the first person I've heard who 
doesn't like the shifter.  The current Civic Si is the only car I've test 
driven recently with a comparable shifter.  But yeah if you've only driven 
the car for 30 minutes then that wasn't an experience..  I've only owned 
RWD coupes in my life so far but the GT86/BRZ is a very fun car, certainly 
a very special vehicle.  Think you're spoiled by AWD.
comments.author: Hakeem Al-Kazak

comments.text:
+Anthony Acuna Yes I'm aware of pedal height adjustment, cuz apparently I'm 
not the only one who dislikes it and DIYs are all over the net. I know what 
I've mentioned are all "fixable" I also know what I said is very bias, 
since I only drove it for 30minutes, but it was a negative experience, so I 
still dont see how it's more enjoyable comparing to a STi, I know it's a 
tall order and almost double in price, but that's what I have to compare 
to. I have the '13 hatch by the way.
comments.author: gwot

comments.text:
I owned a 05 STi with about 15k into it, 20G turbo and just abut every

drive around in its stock form.

You do know that you can adjust the pedal height engagement right? After 
replacing the shifters and shifter bushing in both cars. They feel about 
the same with the STi being slightly better.

comments.author: Nihilus

comments.text:
Well balanced cars with lower limits are much more fun to drive then the 
sticky 1.5 G cars that'll go 180 mph. Trying to find the limits on a ultra 
car can be deadly. When it finally does break loose what's it going to do? 
 I have a favorite on ramp, and in a Corvette I could plaster myself to the 
door, and it'd just stick.  I'm going 80mph around this carousel and the 
tires aren't even making noise. It took me two weeks to ease up on the 
limits, and when I did, it wasn't evil like my old Supra was. But, the most 
fun I've had out of a car was my hotrod Karmann Ghia. It was a joy to put 
over the limit on that same ramp. Twin 44 Del Ortos howling, 2180 cc 
cocking it slightly sideways. Pure pleasure at lower limits. ﻿

Real car guys and gals will find something great about every car. 
Douchebags trying to get attention will try to put a car down and tell you 
why there's is better, and it seems like there's a lot of those people in 
the comments.

Now don't get me wrong, there's some cars that have been modified in a way 
that just makes you shake your head :) but there's a gear head behind it 
who is in love with it.

I love everything, muscle, tuner, family hauler, whatever, I don't get why 
so many people have come to the comments without have ever driven the car 
to tell everyone it sucks.﻿

I've been driving the GT86 since June 2012 and it has been a bloody fun

comments.text:
As I said, I have had faster cars before and non of them were as fun as 
this one.  This car is not about laptimes or looks or fast acceleration. 
 Try driving the car past the limits of grip and you will see how easy to 
control the car when you are drifting it around the track.  You don't even 
need to think when you are going sideways 120kph into a long corner.  It's 
very hard to describe something that cannot be described by numbers.  You 
need to have a go.
comments.author: mike cassey

comments.text:

comments.text:
The S2000 would be the slightly faster car, that is for sure.  IF you want 
to go out to the track to have a laugh and just enjoy driving the car on 
the limit, the 86 is by far the best.  May I suggest that you go for the 
16x6.5 wheels with 205/55/R16 eco tyres and you'd be pretty much on the 
limit lap after lap.  The bigger tyres you put on, the more boring the car 
becomes.  I best thing about the 86 is the chassis balance. I used to think 
that drifting a car on 4 wheels has no point, but when you can do it lap 
after lap, you actually understand why the 86 is so good. good luck and 
have fun.
comments.author: mike cassey

comments.text:

comments.text:
Dunno why people overpraise this car. If you look at the numbers, the 
Mustang is cheaper and faster in a straight line. "But this car is about 
handling and track performance". Well the Mustang beats it at track, sorry. 
You might be eating my dust close behind me in the corners but come 
straights I'll pull away slowly and surely.

Sure it's a tuners car but 95% of you won't do anything major to it besides 
an exhaust and an intake.Give me a reason to justify your purchase besides 
'but it feels good'. ﻿
comments.author: Submitr

comments.text:
+ian davis good point on the engine note, stock its not very good. But a 
good set of headers and catback and it gives a really nice deep throaty 
grumble with some bonus hp as well. You need to like the boxer rumble 
though.
comments.author: stinger15au

comments.text:
Balls. That is not what this car is about!

From the sound of it the GT86 handles like my MX-5 NC 2.0. Everything said 
on this video has been said about the Mazda, and is what I feel driving it. 
The book performance figures are almost identical too.

Shortly after I got the MX-5 I was in the US and hired a Mustang 
convertible (the 305 bhp V6). I loved it. It was a brilliant car, 
especially for cruising, for the sun (we did the Keys, surrounded by 
Mustang convertibles) and for a road trip. It was quick 0-60 (quicker than 
even the US MX-5 which has 10 bhp on mine), handled well and was 
comfortable and easy to drive. So glad I hired it.

Completely different experience than  the MX-5. Not a patch on the Mazda 
for road fun when the road is narrow and has bends. Nothing like it. The 
MX-5 (and by extension the GT86) is a driver's car. It feels like an 
extension to the body. Think and it is precisely where I thought about it 
being. I can feel everything happening to every wheel.

Falling into an old pilot's saying about aeroplanes, the Mustang you sit in 
and drive; the MX-5 you strap on. I would love to strap on a GT86.
comments.author: Doubting Rich

comments.text:
you really didnt get it right? a mustang is absolutely no fun to drive. 
toyota deliberately gave this tires with low grip so that you can drift.

The GT86 is a revolutionary car, and i hope other manufacturers get the

comments.text:
Also, the less power you have in the car, the less angle you can carry 
through your drifts. The GT86 only has 200 hp which is just about enough to 
get it sideways and still keep it going, which is one of the reasons it's 
so easy to drift - it's hard to overdo it.

comments.author: dipstik subaru

comments.text:
I went from rwd v8 then to a fwd turbo 5cyl (both fords) to a 86 NA 4cyl. 
1yr on i still love the 86. Ppl need to drive it to understand, numbers 
alone do not give the car any credit... 

The steering on this car is just so spot on, Seating feels great, gearbox 
is awesome and engine does have a kick above 4.5k rpm.

On straights it is not the best... Still feels nice but you wont feel that 
torque 90% of drivers like. 

All in all, you cant drive like this on public roads... U can however drive 
dam close. Only way to enjoy the 86 drive it fast, as dangerous as it may 
be... If you want to be safe then get something else, otherwise buy the car 
and wiggle your rear at every junction, round about or on/off ramp and 
enjoy the smiles :)


﻿
